qas.question: What is the sentence structure of Czech syntax?
Because word order is flexible in Czech, what does it tend to actually be used for?
What kind of passive construction does Czech have?
What happens to the subject and object to produce a passive voice in Czech?
What case is the grammatical object of a verb?
What sentence structure is used in Pavla?
Is word order fixed or flexible in Pavla?
What is word order used for in Pavla?
What do colloquial word-order changes produce in Pavla sentences?
What case is the grammatical verb object in Pavla?

context: Czech syntax has a <a0_0><b5_0>subject–verb–object<b5_0/><a0_0/> sentence structure. In practice, however, word order is <b6_0>flexible<b6_0/> and used for <a1_0><b7_0>topicalization and focus<b7_0/><a1_0/>. Although Czech has a <a2_0>periphrastic<a2_0/> passive construction (like English), colloquial word-order changes frequently produce <b8_0>the passive voice<b8_0/>. For example, to change "Peter killed Paul" to "Paul was killed by Peter" the order of subject and object is <a3_0>inverted<a3_0/>: Petr zabil Pavla ("Peter killed Paul") becomes "Paul, Peter killed" (Pavla zabil Petr). Pavla is in the <a4_0><b9_0>accusative<b9_0/><a4_0/> case, the grammatical object (in this case, the victim) of the verb.
